sub_topics.title: Safety in the immediate environment
competences: Demonstrate safety practices in the immediate environment

teacher_steps: Introduce the phrase (safety in the immediate environment)

Explain the terminology safety. Explain immediate environment as any surrounding (e.g. home, playground, road) that influences ones behavior and decision likely to bring about accidents, injuries and death without proper measures.

Demonstrate the best safety measures to be taken in specialized and regular rooms. For example, proper storage of some sharp items (e.g. knives, hoe, axe, building tools) likely to make children with visual impairments have serious injuries.
Proper arrangement of furniture with enough space in between desks for easy movements of each and every learner.

Pair learners to practice the best safety measures in specialized and regular classrooms in a dialogue format

Practice choral repetition of key terminologies
Work in pairs to practice safety measures in dialogue format
Rotate pairs to ensure everyone practices with different partners

teacher_steps: Put learners in small groups. Ask learners to role-play a scenario where they are practicing how to clean and store equipment in correct places.
Ask each group to perform their dialogue in front of the class.
Provide feedback

Learners will be given an opportunity to explore the environment to prevent any unforeseen circumstances and practice safety rules. Applying correct safety measures is an essential innovation skill that brings about confidence as someone navigates the immediate environment around them.

sub_topics.title: Body Posture

teacher_steps: The teacher explains the term body posture. Body posture is the way the body is positioned including whether one is standing or sitting, the relative positions of body parts, and how much space the body occupies.
Illustrate to learners how men and women in uniform stand or how people stand when they are singing the national anthem. Then ask learners what the two groups of people have in common.
Thereafter, state exactly what good posture is. Good posture refers to the way a person stands, sits and moves where there is proper body alignment.
Demonstrate to the learners the different correct postural habits such as sitting, standing, walking, kneeling and lifting etc.
learner_steps: Listen to explanation of body posture
Observe illustrations of people with good posture
Identify common characteristics of good posture
Learn about proper body alignment
Observe demonstrations of correct postural habits
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Explanation on the meaning of body posture

teacher_steps: Put the learners in pairs and ask them to practice the correct posture habits.
learner_steps: Work in pairs
Practice correct posture habits with partner
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Pair work to demonstrate correct posture habits

teacher_steps: Put learners in small groups. Ask learners to demonstrate correct postural habits.
Provide feedback
learner_steps: Form small groups
Demonstrate correct postural habits
Receive feedback from teacher
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Individual performance of correct postural habits

sub_topics.short_notes: The purpose of this topic is basic postural skills or habits. Body posture is very much connected to safety. Some accidents or injuries may be brought about due to bad body posture habits. Therefore, learners should be taught good body posture habit for safety reasons. Basic posture exercises will also improve motor skills, balance and make it easier for the learners with visual impairment to use the leg, body and arms properly and prevent accidents.

vocabulary.definition: the way the body is positioned including whether one is standing or sitting, the relative positions of body parts, and how much space the body occupies
being in an upright position on one's feet
resting with the body supported by one's buttocks
raising something to a higher position
being in or moving into a position in which the body is supported by a knee or the knees
moving at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn

questions: What is the meaning of the term body posture?

sub_topics.short_notes: This topic provides learning experiences that are designed to meet children at their skill level and expand skills within their level of competence. Educational gymnastics centers on balance as a lifelong skill, on self-responsibility, and on respect for self and others. Here, children will perform simple tumbling activities such as forward roll, cartwheel and frog jump. Further, learners are expected to perform simple stunts activities including arm, trunk, leg rolling, squatting, balancing.

sub_topics.short_notes: This topic aims at imparting knowledge and skills in learners in performing various athletics activities. Athletics is a sport in which athletes compete in running, walking, jumping and throwing events. Track events consist of running and walking races of various distances while Field on the other side includes jumping and throwing events. Track and field events are important to learners with visual impairment as they improve cognitive, physical and emotional wellbeing. They are also useful in maintaining good body shape and posture, reducing stress and enhancing performance, as well as orientation and mobility.
